facts.text: Appellant was an Upper Division Clerk in the office of the Chief Commissioner of Delhi.
Ram Narain was a fireman serving in Delhi Fire Brigade and chief prosecution witness.
Ram Narain anxious to obtain licence for double-barrelled shotgun and sought appellant's assistance, though appellant had nothing to do with issuing licences (handled by Deputy Commissioner, Delhi).
In 1953, Ram Narain submitted two applications for licence with appellant's assistance; no results.
In 1954, Ram Narain approached appellant again; appellant held out hopes for Rs. 250; Ram Narain paid Rs. 140 and promised balance after sister's marriage.
Third application in 1954 declared Ram Narain's salary as Rs. 105 per month (falsely, actual Rs. 85); licence granted.
Authorities discovered true salary Rs. 85; licence cancelled; Ram Narain called to show cause why prosecuted for false statement.
Ram Narain alleged in representation that appellant advised false salary declaration.
Appellant demanded Rs. 180 for restoring licence; Ram Narain agreed to pay Rs. 90 in advance, balance later.
Ram Narain informed superior officers; matter reached Chief Fire Officer who informed police.
On August 5, 1954, police laid trap; Ram Narain met appellant in Chief Commissioner's office, went to canteen run by Kishorilal (DW1).
Sarwan Singh (taxi driver, PW) and Head Constable Gurbachan Singh (plain clothes, PW) present.
Ram Narain handed Rs. 90 (police money) to appellant; on signal, Inspector Surendra Pal Singh (PW16) entered.
Appellant attempted to hand money to Kishorilal; seized by Head Constable Gurbachan Singh.
FIR drawn at Civil Lines Police Station at 2:30 PM on August 5, 1954.
Trial before Special Judge Shri Jawala Dass, Delhi; charge framed under s.161 IPC or alternatively s.5(1)(d)/s.5(2) PCA.
Special Judge convicted under s.5(1)(d) r/w s.5(2) PCA; 6 months RI.
Appeal to Punjab High Court (Criminal Appeal No. 173-C of 1956); Mr. Justice Falshaw affirmed conviction and sentence on February 4, 1957.
Special leave granted by Supreme Court.
Before single High Court Judge, not disputed that appellant used good offices to expedite application.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts, an offence under s.5(1)(d) of the Prevention of Corruption Act is made out, particularly if the public servant did not misconduct in discharge of his own duty.
Reconsideration of State of Ajmer v. Shivji Lal on interpretation of s.5(1)(d) PCA.

petitioner_arguments.text: No offence under s.5(1)(d) PCA on findings of fact, as public servant must misconduct in discharge of his own duty; relied on State of Ajmer v. Shivji Lal.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: State of Ajmer v. Shivji Lal (1959 Supp. 2 SCR 739); s.5(1)(d) Prevention of Corruption Act

respondent_arguments.text: Prosecution story accepted; appellant abused position as public servant to obtain money.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.5(1)(d) r/w s.5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act

court_reasoning.text: State of Ajmer v. Shivji Lal requires reconsideration; 'in discharge of his duty' is heading/nomenclature, not essential ingredient of s.5(1)(d).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ingredients of s.5(1)(d): (1) public servant; (2) corrupt/illegal means or abusing position; (3) obtains valuable thing/pecuniary advantage; (4) for self/others. No need for 'discharge of own duty'.

court_reasoning.text: Duty and misconduct are antithetical; s.5 creates new offence wider than s.161 IPC, no need for official act motive.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Error in Shivji Lal from misreading section; cl.(d) does not require misconduct in discharge of own duty.

court_reasoning.text: Even if public servant corrupts another, abuses own position; offence made out here as appellant abused position despite no direct duty in licensing.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant took advantage of official position and Ram Narain's ignorance.

court_reasoning.text: Reference to cl.(c) s.5(1): misappropriation not 'in discharge of duty'; cites Hori Ram Singh v. Crown.

holdings.text: Offence under s.5(1)(d) r/w s.5(2) PCA does not require public servant to act in discharge of his own duty; Shivji Lal decision erroneous.
Facts establish appellant abused position as public servant to obtain Rs.90.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Ajmer v. Shivji Lal
precedents_cited.relevance: Held that s.5(1)(d) requires misconduct in discharge of own duty; court holds this misreads section.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hori Ram Singh v. The Crown
precedents_cited.relevance: Misappropriation not in discharge of official duty; illustrates 'discharge of duty' not ingredient of misconduct.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hori Ram Singh v. The King-Emperor
precedents_cited.relevance: Privy Council refused special leave from above decision.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Distinguished from PCA s.5; requires motive/reward for official act, unlike s.5(1)(d).

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines criminal misconduct by abusing position to obtain pecuniary advantage; conviction upheld.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; conviction under s.5(1)(d) r/w s.5(2) of Prevention of Corruption Act and sentence of six months rigorous imprisonment affirmed; State of Ajmer v. Shivji Lal overruled on interpretation of s.5(1)(d).

key_quotes.text: "The words 'in the discharge of his duty' do not constitute an essential ingredient of the offence."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding overruling Shivji Lal on s.5(1)(d) ingredients.

key_quotes.text: "Duty and misconduct go ill together. If a person has misconducted himself as a public servant, it would not ordinarily be in the discharge of his duty, but the reverse of it."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why 'discharge of duty' cannot be ingredient of misconduct under s.5.

key_quotes.text: "The legislature advisedly widened the scope of the crime by giving a very wide definition in s.5 with a view to punish those who holding public office and taking advantage of their official position obtain any valuable thing or pecuniary advantage."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies broad interpretation of PCA s.5.
